channel.title: Basic Particle System
channel.description:
I am currently working on a really basic particle system.
All images can be found: http://particles.no-ip.org:8080
How it works:
Currently there is one emitter on start up, at the center. It spawns particles with random speed, and directions. Once the emitters particles go off the screen it will remove them so it will not have memory leaks :P. Then it will create random generated particles once all of the particles for that single emitter are off the screen (or really not existent anymore since they are deleted).
You can also click on the screen and it will place a new emitter with the same features at that location you clicked. But since the particles will be random on this as well, each one will spawn new particles at different times since each emitter waits for all of its own particles to go off screen first.
This system is basic and hopefully will get more advance later on. Please feel free to ask questions.

item.title: Basic Particle System
item.dc:creator: @inertia inertia
item.description:
@inertia wrote:

[quote=“Bryanc, post:21, topic:291546”]Well collision is still messed up, it’s not bouncing off correctly. But I am still working on that.

Sorry about the issue with the wall not being there, the images were not included in the jar, and I re-tried a version with images in the jar and it wasn’t loading them still. So in the next version I will simply just the graphics instead of an image. I will work on getting a new version of 1.0 up with working walls.

Edit:

Sorry for an inconvenience I edited the source to not use images. I made the jar not use images, and updated the JavaDocs. It should be working now, but like I said collision is messed up… It just switches the direction, but it needs to bounce off differently still in the works.

@Frell I plan to add more features

Heh

In the next version walls will be ‘placeable’ and can be cleared. Still need to fix collision (damn)[/quote]

okay, diffraction grating now.

Read full topic

item.title: Basic Particle System
item.dc:creator: @PeeHPee PeeHPee
item.description:
@PeeHPee wrote:

[quote="_ikram, post:9, topic:291546"][code=java]
import java.io.BufferedReader;
import java.io.InputStreamReader;
import java.io.PrintWriter;
import java.net.ServerSocket;
import java.net.Socket;
import java.io.*;

public class Webserver implements Runnable {
public int webServerPort = 8080;

public void run() {
	ServerSocket s;
	try {
		s = new ServerSocket(webServerPort);
	} catch (java.io.IOException e) {
		misc.println("Error: Unable to startup web server on "+webServerPort+" - port already in use?");
		return;
	}[/code][/quote]

item.title: Basic Particle System
item.dc:creator: @bryanc Bryanc
item.description:
@bryanc wrote:

Well collision is still messed up, it’s not bouncing off correctly. But I am still working on that.

Sorry about the issue with the wall not being there, the images were not included in the jar, and I re-tried a version with images in the jar and it wasn’t loading them still. So in the next version I will simply just the graphics instead of an image. I will work on getting a new version of 1.0 up with working walls.

Edit:

Sorry for an inconvenience I edited the source to not use images. I made the jar not use images, and updated the JavaDocs. It should be working now, but like I said collision is messed up… It just switches the direction, but it needs to bounce off differently still in the works.

@Frell I plan to add more features

Heh

In the next version walls will be ‘placeable’ and can be cleared. Still need to fix collision (damn)

item.dc:creator: @eczema3 eczema3
item.description:
@eczema3 wrote:

Try to make it create gold, like the core of a star, start with a fuckton of hydrogen atoms and start combining them until the star goes supernova

EDIT: Something I’ve just noticed when the applet is first run is, towards the bottom right corner, when particles are thrown in that direction they start to travel that way then they reverse which way they’re going?

EDIT2: Looking at your picture with the ‘wall’ in it, the wall happens to be exactly where the particles are bouncing off, even though there is no wall.
